Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 07:39AM abbadoodles wrote: Candy, everyone is scared of such major sugery.  Mastectomy is generally outpatient surgery these days unless there are complications.  But, outpatient can and does mean overnight in many places.  It's an insurance thing.  In my state, under 24 hours is outpatient even if they admit you to a room. I was not in pain at all after the surgery and just a little sore from disuse of the arm for a few days.  Your doctor/nurses will let you know how much you are to move your arms and if they advise movement, make sure you follow instructions as you can very, very quickly develop a frozen shoulder if you are not using your arm(s) at all.  You will have excercises to start performing soon after surgery.  Other than the lifting restrictions, you should be pretty mobile.  I was working (at home) within a few days of surgery, with no problems.  You won't be able to drive at least while on pain meds if you take them and until a certain amount of healing has taken place.  I was driving two weeks later.  It varies.  But, most docs rec several weeks at home. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Scared CandyLuna ailenroc

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2007 11:02AM - edited Oct 23, 2009 04:34AM by abbadoodles t
Posts.Title: the emotional toll of hair loss Mandy41 Phebe38

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 01:16PM abbadoodles wrote: formygirls, I only had the bone pain about a week after the first shot, never again after any of the others. My pain was a wave-like spasm in my lower back, about where the kidneys are.  It started around 7 AM and lasted for about 12 hours, then left just as suddenly as it started.  I took an Advil, which did help. It's extremely variable, as with so many of these treatments and drugs.  Hard to advise anyone on what to expect. Good luck for the rest of treatments.
Posts.Title: Bone pain in second week with Neulasta? formygirls SpecialK

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2009 11:08AM abbadoodles wrote: Elliana, that's great about your results but not so great about the nausea.  Do you think you picked up a bug while in the joint?  It may be unrelated to your surgery.  I hope it passes soon.
Posts.Title: Persistant Nausea after Lumpectomy Elliana bbop53

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2007 05:47AM abbadoodles wrote: EGAL, the poodle "do" is at least not as bad as bald!!!  Heh Heh.  My own DH just cracks me up; every now and then he looks at me, bangs his right clenched fist to his heart and gives me the "Hail, Ceasar!" routine.  Gotta love that guy.    What would I do without him?  Actually, he tells me if I had blond hair I would look just like Jamie Leigh Curtis.  Now, that's better than Ceasar! Just had my first hairdresser appt. last week.  He didn't cut anything as what I have is really nice around the face but cutting would have given me more of a blunt look.  Even the long curlies at the nape of my neck look a bit "flirty" according to him.  Gad, what a sweetheart!  He did teach me to use a styling product (he used Goldwell's Lagoom) to apply just to the roots and either use a vent brush and dryer or just leave to air dry.  This helps "lift" the base of the hairs for more fullness on the sides to match the top, which is SO thick and poppy-uppy!!!  Anyway, it works pretty well and I'd be almost entirely happy with my hair for the time-being if it were not for the lack of bangs, which I really need on my high forehead. Another woman on these boards said she had very good luck with a Redken product called Rewind.  Tina

Be well and at peace.
Posts.Title: OK on the outside, YIKES on inside! ghety Mykidsmom

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 07:46AM abbadoodles wrote: Barb, don't you have adjustment straps inside your wigs on both sides?  Mine does; it's a Louis Ferre.  I can make the wig tighter or looser.  I did notice that when it was too tight the ear tabs (which are supposed to always be in front of your ears) would interfere with my glasses and cause my left ear to ache.   Just loosening it up one notch cured that problem. I wore my wig from week 3 of chemo (around April 20, 2007) until this past week when I decided I had enough hair to go topless.  OMG, you should see the curls!!!  Just like a little poodle. LOL Tina
Posts.Title: Wig help Barbeqrn Barbeqrn

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 05:31AM abbadoodles wrote: Barb, my wig is monofilament.  It really is not itchy except when some of the fibers work their way to the inside.  Try taking a fine crochet hook and pulling them out again if that is one of your problems.  A liner may work but be hotter for you.  Yeah, Florida is still darn hot! Tina
Posts.Title: Wig help Barbeqrn Barbeqrn

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2007 06:44AM abbadoodles wrote: Barb, you are, of course, right.  One of the most disconcerting things about all of this is that we all respond differently.  Comparisons can be dangerous! Although it took a long time for my hair to wake up, it has been growing gangbusters.  Of course, it is pretty curly, too, so doesn't look as long as it really is. Oh, well.  It is very thick, too.  My hair before chemo was thick and wavy and grew like the dickens. Tina

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2009 03:51PM abbadoodles wrote: I don't remember what was prescribed for me after my mx/TE placement but I never had to use it.  Never had any pain.  Same for after flap surgeries.  For those I had one of those IV pain pumps with morphine.  Never used a drop.  Just lucky I guess.  We're all so different.  The nurses and docs kept asking me about my "pain" but I kept telling them I didn't have any.  They thought I was kidding or in denial.  Go figure.  It's a shame that someone like you that HAD pain had to go without relief.
Posts.Title: Pain medicine for mastectomy--survey tracyanne tracyanne

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 12:01AM abbadoodles wrote: Anne, I am so sorry you are experiencing this.  I had a mere 12 hours or so of nerve pain 16 years ago after an axillary LND; it was like hot, barbed wire being drawn through my axilla and only happened when I moved a certain way.  Thank God it resolved itself quickly as I do not think I could have tolerated it much longer.  At the time, the surgeon said nothing could be done to help it! Actually, it may be that the stitching from your new surgery is impinging on a sensitive area and it maybe possible to go in and re-arrange things.  I know that I have some neurapraxia from my last surgery and the neurologist said if it does't resolve by itself within 2-3 months it may be necessary to go back in and check that some nerve isn't being irritated. I hope you feel better really soon. Hugs.
Posts.Title: Oh, crap--NERVE PAIN!! AnneW AnneW

Posts.Title: Options stacymo pinoideae

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 06:24AM abbadoodles wrote: My own experience is that I was dx with Ca at the age of 44 and had a lumpectomy with radiation.  Unfortunately, I developed another tumor in the same breast at age 59.  Having had the radiation has greatly complicated the reconstruction process.  If I had to do it over again, I would have just had a mastectomy the first time with recon.  Today, the recon options are even greater than they were 16 years ago.  That being said, no recon is the same as your own breast but you can have some very good cosmetic results. Again, just my own experience and feelings.

BTW, the lashes will probably fall out a couple more times, every three months or so.  Bah. Tina

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 09:12AM abbadoodles wrote: A real hair wig will have to be styled just like a real head of hair.  It will behave as natural hair, but it's hard to say just how since real hair wigs may be made from a type of hair that is not similar to your own.  I understand lots of them are made of Asian hair, which, although lovely, has very different properties from my own.  You may even have to set a real hair wig. The beauty of a synthetic wig is that not only do many of them look very real but all the upkeep they require is a wash every few wearings and can be left to dry naturally.  Whatever style they are will come back just like magic.  No styling!
Posts.Title: Real Hair Wigs - maintenance newmex1598 lisasayers

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 01:18PM - edited Feb 28, 2008 01:19PM by abbadoodles Harley, try Aubrey's Organics line.  Here is their site.  I've bought this stuff at my local health foods store.  Whole Foods should carry it. http://www.aubrey-organics.com/about/articles/healthy11.cfm I have dry-ish hair and started using the White Camellia shampoo and conditioner.  You have to get used to the shampoo not lathering but still cleaning.  Also, you must really rinse, rinse, rinse the conditioner out.  But, it is lovely stuff and made me hair nice and shiny for the first time in a long time. They do have a couple of hair colors, too. At the moment I am using the Deva line.  Their stuff is also natural but I don't think organic. Tina
Posts.Title: 4 Months Later - Sparse Eyebrows & Roadkill Hair SueB46 abbadoodles

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 10:36AM abbadoodles wrote: MaryJo, I had a horrible problem with runny nose/weepy eyes towards the end of A/C and for about a month afterward.  Actually, now, 8 months after finishing tx, I still have an issue but it is much dimished. I found that Systane eye drops were the only thing that helped the eye situation and lotion-treated tissues were best for the runny nose.  Regular tissues made my skin so raw I couldn't touch my poor nose. Tina

BTW, my onc's nurse practitioner knew what the problem was and about the sore nose she advised a little Bacitracin ointment in the nostrils.  It does work to heal those nose sores. Tina

Posts.Title: chemotherapy side effects hobblet abbadoodles

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2008 07:10AM abbadoodles wrote: bettelou, I'm surprised you went back two days after chemo for your Neulasta.  I had read somewhere that the shot MUST be given no more than 24 hours after the A/C tx.
Posts.Title: Working During Chemo zuffa kjbell

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2008 12:16PM abbadoodles wrote: I had DD A/C every two weeks on a Thursday.  Fridays I went back for the Neulasta.  I felt fine both days and even Saturday and most of Sunday.  Later in the day on Sundays and Mondays and Tuesdays were my worst.  I never really got sick-sick, no nausea, but was quite tired to the point of exhaustion for those couple of days.  I was too "spaced out" to get much work done.  (I have my own business.) So, I would consider planning on working the day of and the day after treatment and then scaling back the next few days, particularly days 4,5, and 6 if you count tx day as Day 1. Good luck.  I was 60 when I went through it and did just fine.  I hope you do, too.
Posts.Title: Working During Chemo zuffa kjbell

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 07:54AM abbadoodles wrote: I craved and thoroughly enjoyed green salads with lots of Italian or Ceasar dressing.  I really HATE salads in real life but while on A/C I couldn't get enough of them.  Of course, I could hardly taste a thing. Even water was like soap. I did crave potato sticks not chips.  Now, off chemo, I can take them or leave them. Chemicals do weird things to your body........... Tina

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2008 05:29PM abbadoodles wrote: The classification is based upon your insurance; they all call it different things. My uni mx was in the regular operating suite in the hospital and I did stay overnight, but because I left within the 24 hour max. it was coded as outpatient.    You may find that you will be admitted to a room after your "outpatient" surgery.  Why don't you call the surgical center and ask what to expect?
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy as 23-hour outpatient econmom Scrappygrl

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 07:51AM abbadoodles wrote: Hi, Joy, I had a similar response to the chemo.  Mine was A/C.  For a few days after treatment, I had that loud pounding of blood in my ears; I could hardly sleep for the pounding.  I did get shots of Neulasta and one shot of Arasept (like Procrit) as my red count started to go down.  I bled easily, too. Well, my onc was not concerned.  I guess as long as you're still standing, they think you're okay.   Well, it all turned out okay.  That's just my own experience so you know you're not alone.  But you do need to bring it all to the attention of the docs and find out about your blood counts. Tina

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 12:47PM abbadoodles wrote: Good idea, Marin.  I don't have a pic but I looked down into the sink this morning and there was a hair that had fallen out of my head!  First one I've noticed since it started growing in.  It was 4 1/2" long!  That took 9 months since I finished A/C only chemo in mid to late May 07.  Bear in mind that it DID NOT start growing until about the Fourth of July.  Doing the math, that's at least 1/2" per month if you figure from mid May, much more if you figure from July 4.  That outta encourage current chemo girls. BTW, I look like a cross between Harpo Marx and Lyle Lovett.  I mean, LOTS of thick and curly hair.  Gee, maybe that doesn't sound so encouraging.   Well, it's great hair, hair, hair. Also, based on Marin's recommendation, I started taking 1mg Biotin as supplement daily.  Tina

Now that my hair is back to normal, I really, really miss my curls!  You may, too. Everyone enjoy your new hair!

Now, one year later, it's hotter than heck outside and my hair is so long and thick I am suffering greatly.  Cannot find it in myself to complain too loudly, though.............am waiting for the cooler fall weather now.  Don't forget to look into the Biotin!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 09:09AM abbadoodles wrote: Ha ha.  I had the Skeezix look at first, too.  It does go away over time.  Well, actually, it doesn't go away it just gets incorporated into your new mass of hair.  If I look at my hair now, over a year out of A/C chemo, it is clearly growing up in front before it flops over and goes down.  This is the same way it was before chemo, just never really took note of it. BTW, my brows only fell out once about 5-6 weeks after last dose of A/C (no taxols) but my lashes fell out fully four times, then a little at a time for a sixth time and now are falling out very, very slowly and coming back at the same time so it isn't noticeable.  This has been happening every three months.  Grrrrrrr.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 09:00AM - edited Jun 16, 2008 11:31AM by abbadoodles Yes, go to the Moving Beyond category, then look for the "Hair Growth Pictures" thread.  I also want to add that the type of chemo you have had generally affects the timing and pattern of hair regrowth.  If you go from A/C to a taxane, you may start seeing regrowth while still on the taxane. And, yes, many people report that their initial hair growth is colorless or looks gray but then starts to show color.  Mine was just my old mix of brown and some gray.  Very unattractive at first and not all over at once, sort of moth-eaten LOL.  Not so funny at the time. I also lost brows and lashes about five or six weeks out from my last A/C.  Then, I've lost my lashes four times, that is, every three months since then.  How's THAT for a pip?
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 09:30AM abbadoodles wrote: Runny nose update:  The trigger for my nose running is movement.  That's right, everything is fine until I start moving around.  No sinus problems or allergies at all.  It has to do with blood flow. Same with teary eyes.  No blocked ducts, just runny eyes.  I saw my onc for my 8 month checkup last week and mentioned the runny/weepy syndrome.  She wasn't too concerned.  Just said, Huh.  That's unusual and went on to the next thing.  I guess if we are not bleeding from all orifices or fainting in front of them, we are okay enough.   Tina
Posts.Title: lingering s/e runny nose/weepy eyes abbadoodles abbadoodles

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 04:59AM abbadoodles wrote: Gee, I never had a sick moment the day of the infusion of A/C.  Or the next day, or the next.  On the third and fourth days AFTER chemo I did feel very tired and just flopped around from couch to bed and did some deskwork in between.  Not highly productive but did get some work done.  NEVER was queasy or threw up.  Of course, I did take Emend the day of chemo and two days after, plus the anti-nausea IV chemo meds (I think Zofran and some steroid) just before infusion and then the steroid for the next two days.  That was it.  I hope you have the same good luck, if you can call it that.
Posts.Title: How long... theprettiestmess abbadoodles

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 06:23AM abbadoodles wrote: I also had 4 DD A/C via my veins on my only usable side (LND on other) and had zero problems.  My onc had offered to put in a port but my bs implied it wasn't necessary so I went with his guidance.  Perhaps different oncs have different preferences; I'm also sure your particular condition and history will affect any decisions.  You also need to know that you can start without a port but have one put in later if you run into difficulty with infusions. Good luck. Tina
Posts.Title: Using your veins instead of a port for chemo infusions otter joteach

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2007 02:26PM - edited Sep 12, 2007 02:27PM by abbadoodles Angel, I'm with you on the hair coloring.  What do they think we are, crazy or just stupid?  Hey, they can pump us up with stuff that can kill us immediately but whoooooaa, no dear, don't apply any possible poisons to your hair. Gimme a break.  OTOH, I do believe in testing the waters!  I started out with Loving Care and will continue with that for several months before moving on to more permanent color.  Re rate of regrowth:  I did not have one speck of new growth until a full 6 weeks post chemo (finished 5/17/07) and now have at least 1.5 inches less then four months later.  So, you may catch up faster than you think. Cheers on the journey! Tina
Posts.Title: If Your Hair Grows in Gray or White figsgirls Diana63

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2007 05:49PM abbadoodles wrote: Harley, I think you read that wrong.  I had NO hair at 6 weeks post chemo, but now in September, almost 4 MONTHS after finishing chemo there is at least 1.5 inches.  However, remember that this is growth that only started showing around the Fourth of July.  That makes it about 2 months' growth.  So, yes, it really started going bonkers once it decided to show up!  I was sooooooo worried that it would never show because so many people on these boards say that their hair started re-growing while they were STILL ON chemo.  I guess my situation was a little different because I did not go on for Taxol or Taxotere after I finished A/C. I hope that clears things up.  Tina

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 12:17PM abbadoodles wrote: Does anyone have a good idea for attaching a small, zippered, cosmetics bag to the side of the bed/ bedrails in the hospital?  I plan on taking a few things (chapstick, blush, cell phone, etc.) and keeping them in a clear pouch at bedside.  As I know from prior experience that it's not always easy to reach things on the bedside or over-the-bed table, I plan on attaching it to the bed itself.  The zipper that closes the bag has a nice round hole in it and I can use that to string something through.  The something has to both fit through and be short in length to fit around the bedrail and yet not flop down too far.  I'm thinking something kinds flat with Velcro dots sewn onto the ends.  Maybe there is something already out there that doesn't need to be homemade??? Tina

Good luck, sweetie.  It sure is a cruddy time. Tina

In your case, the onc may want to use everything she can as you are triple neg. But, no, taxol is not always prescribed or necessary after A/C.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 01:41AM abbadoodles wrote: Mine has been coming in the same length all over.  It came in dark, at least as dark as it was before chemo, but with the attendant gray, too!   Same as before. Also, some people here talk about it being like baby hair at first, sometimes even colorless, but mine was wasn't.  It's about 3-4 inches now and coarse as ever but curly as the dickens.  It looks much shorter because of that. I have not had a cut at all and I'm 8 months post A/C.  I have had it colored to cover the gray but the hairdresser keeps talking me out of cutting it as he says it looks great just the way/shape it is and he couldn't do better.  I, personally, am wondering if it isn't getting just a bit out of hand now, though.  Maybe I'll MAKE him trim it next week. LOL Everyone has a different story. Tina
Posts.Title: What do u do when yer hair starts growing back? paxton Myrajuc

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2007 03:51PM abbadoodles wrote: Kathy, everyone is different. I do know that if I had had only and 8% chance of recurrance, I would not have done the A/C.  Adriamycin can cause heart failure in future years and also leukemias, but I'm not sure of the percentages.  If you lower your risk from 8 to 3.5, isn't that just a 4.5% advantage?  What if the risk of heart failure and other cancers were then 2 to 10%? You have to be willing to take responsibility for whatever you do.  Good luck. Tina
Posts.Title: Do you think an 8% risk of recurrance is worth doing chemo? kathyv riverinerabbit

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 10:50AM abbadoodles wrote: Oh, yeah, seromas are very common.  You need to watch its progression/regression.  Some doctors believe in draining them and others just want them to resolve themselves. I've had them and never had them drained.  I guess they were not THAT bad. Tina

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 09:09AM abbadoodles wrote: It's true, overall, that a good wig will cost about $200, give or take.  The monofilament wigs are very good, you can see your real scalp through the crown so they're more realistic, some are now with blended colors which look so real.  Be sure to buy from someone who knows how to style wigs, as most wigs will need to be trimmed a bit to fit your face and avoid a "wiggy" look. Many insurance plans will pay for a wig or give a wig allowance if you have a prescription for a cranial prosthesis or some such wordage from one of your doctors. I had either a Louis Ferre or Henri Margu wig and it was so good no one, but no one, knew I was wearing one.

Posts.Title: If Your Hair Grows in Gray or White figsgirls Diana63

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2008 09:28AM abbadoodles wrote: My formerly slightly wavy hair grew back very, very curly.  It is still curly after a bit over a year but I can tell that the hair nearest the roots are somewhat less curly on the top and straighter and straighter towards the nape of my neck.  I'm afraid to cut it as I don't know what point in the curl it will be chopped and how it will look, so I'm leaving well enough alone for another few months. I actually love my curls.  I get TONS of compliments, too.  Many people think it's a wig and they never even noticed my wig when I was wearing one!
Posts.Title: Curly Hair - does it stay or go? Maple Maple

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2007 04:58PM abbadoodles wrote: Almost everyone loses their brows and lashes.  I lost mine 5 weeks after my A/C treatments but they started re-growing immediately and were back fully within a couple of weeks or so. Use a waxy eyeliner pen/pencil to make eyebrows and make small brushstrokes, then blend, blend, blend with either a sponge tip or pointy Q-tip. Use a good eyeliner pencil to make a line (short strokes) on the eyelash line.  Very thin. Then, blend as above.  You would be AMAZED at how convincing these "brows/lashes" can look.  You really won't need false eyelashes.  I bought some but never felt I needed to use them. Good luck.  It's challenging but you WILL get through this. Tina
Posts.Title: eyelashes and brows mkl48 Traci-----TripNeg

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 01:31PM abbadoodles wrote: Poor otter.  Any bad salesperson can really ruin our day but in this case it sure was a drastic result.  I wish I could tell you where to buy a wig.  Online, of course, but you cannot try them on first and I don't think returns are allowed.  Maybe you should call around for a salon that will style a wig, then have the stylist give you some ideas of what to look for in a wig before you buy.  If it's a basic style, you probably can't go too wrong.  Take a look at the styles on www.wigs.com for ideas and prices.
Posts.Title: wigs and hair loss mizz jdg1

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 12:50PM abbadoodles wrote: You will probably be instructed not to wear a bra until at least the drains come out.  That could be one to two weeks or more. There are special post surgical camis that have very convenient detachable pockets for drains; they hook onto a band in the cami with Velcro strips.  Believe me, they are worth every penny, even if you have to buy one.  I think they run about $30 to $35 and many insurance plans cover it in full. Don't forget that you will also have to deal with adb. drains, not just the ones from the chest area.  These you may want to pin onto your panties.  Good luck with your upcoming surgery.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 08:12AM abbadoodles wrote: I had a lumpectomy with rads about 17 years ago, but had another tumor in the same breast just a couple of years ago so I had a mast at that time with expander.  The implant never softened over time because of the previous rads and thin skin.  I ended up with a free TRAM, which was too small, so I had to have another implant under THAT recently. Bottom line is that if I knew then what I know now, I would either have the lumpectomy with no rads or go for the mastectomy in the first place.  As far as I'm concerned, the rads did not work and just caused my further problems down the line.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2008 09:32AM abbadoodles wrote: One thing I have learned from reading the posts on this site for the past year or so is that our responses to all these bodily insults are so different from one woman to another.  Although I know it is human nature to want to know beforehand what to expect from surgery and its recovery, it's probably impossible to know.  If you know the range of experiences, at least you are both forewarned/forearmed and have some upside hope. In my own case, I had a uni mx with expander and had no pain at all so not even one pain med.  Maybe because of that, even though I was tired for a while, I was able to do some computer/paperwork within a week of surgery.  I didn't have the complication of extra sleepiness/drowsiness from pain meds.  Meds can be wonderful but do have side effects.  Just go at your own pace and let yourself relax into the rhythms your own body wants to set.  Good luck for your speedy recovery and the best for 2009.
Posts.Title: Frustrated With Recovery flb1011 2Hands4me

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 06:01AM abbadoodles wrote: Mandy, lots of us have had chemo IV instead of through a port.  Mine was 4 DD A/C, no complications.  Your physicians will help you decide if a port is necessary in your case.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: has anyone had IV chemo? Mandy1313 talbrig13

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 10:35AM abbadoodles wrote: Oh, these stories are just awful!  Luckily, although my onc told me I "could have a port" if I wanted one, my bs said "no."  From prior experience he said not everyone needs one and I could start chemo and see how it went with my veins.  That way, I wouldn't be having any unnecessary surgery and/or inserts (foreign objects installed) and therefore, possible complications.  I wish everyone had the same options! (BTW, I had 4 DD A/C and never had a problem.) I did read on these boards, sometime last summer, the story of a woman whose port was very painful and she complained and complained but nothing was done but some pain meds.  At some point, and I don't remember if it was when she was in such extreme pain they decided to remove it or move it, the port was removed and the pain went away immediately.  Seems it was resting on a nerve or something.  I wish I could find it in the archives.  Maybe someone else remembers the incident.
Posts.Title: Port-a Cath pain? TinaLee Kicks

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2007 09:37AM abbadoodles wrote: God bless and watch over both of you. Tina
Posts.Title: Pixie's Husband Here. I Need Your Prayers. PixieDust wackyjackie

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2007 12:11PM abbadoodles wrote: Ladies, I have to say that you shouldn't pay too much heed to the doomsday crowd.  Everyone's situation is different.  Everyone's disease, treatments, side effects, other reactions, responses, recovery, etc.  I can only tell you that I had bc 15 years ago with lumpectomy and rads and 18 months tamoxifen.  I did just fine with very few se's from anything but the hot flashes from the tamox. (I was 44-45 at the time) got to be too much to bear. This time around, I had a mastectomy and chemo (4 DD A/C) and will not be receiving and hormone therapy as I am ER-PR weakly+, Her-.  I finished chemo on May 17 and had implant exchange surgery two weeks ago.  I actually feel great.  No more tired than I ever was, good energy level.  Hey, I'm 59 now.   No spring chicken! So, don't anticipate the worst.  You may be just fine.  Emotionally, too.  Good luck with the chemo.  Ask lots of questions about what to expect so you are not terrified of some of the lesser manifestations of se's along with the biggies.  Be your own advocate and speak up! Hugs, Tina
Posts.Title: do you ever feel like your old self again? bluewillow bluewillow

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 09:41AM abbadoodles wrote: Yes, Susie, they will continue to fall out for probably at least one more time.  I finished A/C in mid May 07 and my eyebrows and lashes fell out completely about 6 weeks later.  Then, lashes only fell out little by little 3 months after that.  I had hear that would happen.  The only good thing is that by the time I realized they were falling out again, the "early faller-outers" had already begun growing back in, so it didn't take as long to get a full set. Then, as anticipated, about a month ago my lashes started falling out for the third time.  It was more gradual this time and they are all back in but still about 1/2 the normal length.  Still, not looking bad.  I was wondering if this would go on another time or more???  Maybe someone out there can fill us in. Tina
Posts.Title: Losing Eyelashes a 2nd time susieloutoo Tessmerelda

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2008 08:27AM abbadoodles wrote: A caution about gluing anything to your head:  Use of glues and adhesives during chemo is discouraged because of the possibility of infections.  My onc and others even told me not to use false eyelashes because of the glue used to secure them. I did use a monofilament wig during chemo and found it to be very comfortable and not hot unless the weather was hot and humid (over 80 degrees) so I guess that issue depends upon where you are located. Good luck dealing with this trying issue.  Keep the faith; it will end someday and you will go back to normal.
